case_data.name: Lashbrook v. City of San Jose
case_data.plaintiff_description: Artie Lashbrook is an individual from the City of San Jose who is mobility impaired and must use a wheelchair.

case_data.summary:
On February 19, 2020, the main plaintiff filed a complaint against the city of San Jose in the US Court for the Northern District of California alleging that the City failed to build sufficient curb ramps for people with mobility disabilities. Plaintiff is a wheelchair user who has lived in San Jose all his life, and has encountered numerous obstacles in moving around the city, including a non-flush transition at the bottom of a curb ramp in 2017 that caused his wheelchair to tip over and for him to lie on the street for ten minutes. He argued that the city's failure to build sufficient curb ramps at city sidewalks and other pedestrian infrastructure in the city violated Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and California state statutes that were analogous with the latter, namely California Government Code § 11135 and California Civil Code § 54. Plaintiff sought to represent a class of people with mobility disabilities who use or will use the pedestrian right of way in the city. He sought a permanent injunction requiring the City to take remedial measures to repair and maintain curb ramps, and to ensure that all new construction is in accordance with ADA requirements. The case was assigned to US Magistrate Judge Nathaniel Cousins.

On April 21, 2020, the parties jointly filed a motion for approval of a settlement agreement. The settlement proposed a settlement class of all persons (including residents of and/or visitors to the City of San Jose) with any mobility disability who, at any time prior to the Court granting final approval of the Consent Decree, had been denied full and equal access to the City’s pedestrian right of way due to the lack of a curb ramp or a curb ramp that was damaged, in need of repair, or otherwise in a condition not suitable or sufficient for use. Per the agreement, the City agreed to commit 13 million dollars each year to the construction of new curb ramps  and maintenance of the old ones, as well as to institute a system through which mobility impaired citizens could request the construction of new curb ramps or the remediation of existing ramps. Finally, the proposed settlement also included a mandatory reporting period through at least 2038. The settlement also included a damages payment to the main plaintiff of $50,000.

On May 27, 2020, US Magistrate Judge Nathaniel Cousins issued an order certifying the settlement class without modifications and approving the settlement agreement. The court also approved the payment of attorneys' fees.

The case was closed on September 2, 2020.
case_data.summary_short: This suit was filed on February 19, 2020, against the City of San Jose, CA, for not sufficiently maintaining curb ramps and building new ones within the city's pedestrian infrastructure. The parties entered into settlement negotiations and concluded them quickly, issuing a motion for settlement to the judge on April 21, 2020. The settlement was mostly injunctive in nature, assigning 13 million USD per year to the maintenance of existing curb ramps and the construction of new ones, but did include attorney's fees for Lashbrook and a damages payment. The judge approved the conditions of the settlement on May 27, 2020, and the case was officially closed on September 2, 2020.
